Study Description: This experiment tests whether acute stress impairs memory consolidation. The proposed causal pathway is that stress exposure triggers cortisol release, which activates glucocorticoid receptors in the hippocampus and ultimately impairs memory consolidation.
Independent Variable: Acute stress exposure (TSST vs. control condition)
Dependent Variable: Memory performance (percentage of word pairs correctly recalled)

subElements.Experimental Methods: Participants are fitted with galvanic skin response (GSR) electrodes and study a list of 16 semantically related word pairs for 5 minutes (encoding phase)

Participants are randomly assigned to either: - Stress condition: Complete the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) - 5 minutes of public speaking and mental arithmetic in front of evaluators - Control condition: Complete simple math problems and read a short passage quietly for the same duration
GSR data is recorded continuously during the intervention to verify stress induction
subElements.correctness of methods selection: Correct - GSR is an indicator of stress, but it is a direct measure of the hypothesized mediators.
subElements.fix1: Collect saliva samples to measure cortisol levels
subElements.fix2: Use EEG to monitor stress-related brain activity
subElements.fix3: Measure blood pressure changes to measure stress levels
subElements.fix4: Use stress questionnaires before and after the stressor

subElements.Experimental Methods: Participants complete a 15-minute distractor task (sudoku puzzles)
Participants complete a cued recall test where they see the first word of each pair and must recall the second word
subElements.correctness of methods selection: Correct - this measure of memory might be influenced by factors outside our hypothesized mediators.
subElements.fix1: Use fMRI to measure hippocampal activity during the memory task
subElements.fix2: Use a follow-up test at 24 hours to measure long-term retention
subElements.fix3: Compare the GSR stress response for correct and incorrect answers.
subElements.fix4: Ask subjects to rate their confidence for each word pair.

Study Description: This experiment tests whether caffeine improves cognitive performance. The proposed causal pathway is that caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, which normally promote a feeling of sleepiness. This blockage improves alertness, leading to improved cognitive performance.

subElements.Experimental Methods: Subjects are randomly assigned to receive a 200mg caffeine pill or identical-appearing placebo.
subElements.correctness of methods selection: Correct - the dosage might not be an appropriate amount for each individual.
subElements.fix1: Ensure that subjects have not taken caffeine before the experiment
subElements.fix2: Survey the subjects to identify a reasonable dosage based on their average daily intake
subElements.fix3: Provide caffeinated and decaf coffee instead of a pill and placebo.
subElements.fix4: Measure heart rate to ensure that the caffeine has an effect.

subElements.Experimental Methods: Subjects wait 45 minutes for the caffeine to take effect.
Subjects complete a simple reflex task of pressing the spacebar as quickly as possible when a red circle appears on screen, while they attempt to solve simple arithmetic problems.
Average reflex time and total number of correct arithmetic problems are calculated as measures of cognitive performance.
subElements.fix1: Use a comprehensive set of tests that include working memory, attention, and executive function tasks.
subElements.fix2: Use both visual and auditory stimuli to test reflexes
subElements.fix3: Use word association in addition to mathquestions
subElements.fix4: Measure reflex time before caffeine to establish a baseline.
